timeline.bodyText:
Idle thought: I wonder if this parameter should actually be called login_identifier or signin_identifier or user_identifier or identifier (or.. or.... or.....) and this comment should read:

This can be a username (e.g. superdog22), an email address (e.g. superdog22@example.com), or a phone number (e.g. +12125551212), depending upon the configuration...
timeline.author: jpignata
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -34,7 +34,7 @@
      * Creates a new user account with the specified username and password.
      * Can also pass in user attributes to associate with the user through
      * the options object.
-     * @param username This can be a typical username, email, phone number, etc. depending on the configuration
+     * @param username A login identifier e.g. `superdog22`; or an email/phone number, depending on configuration

replies.bodyText: While more accurate, I think that makes it much more difficult to understand. As a developer, in a sign in method, I expect a username and password parameter. And it's not a big leap to understand I can also have email/phone as my username. But any parameter name with "identifier" in it I'm going to be thinking it's a User ID of some sort.
replies.author: TrekSoft

replies.bodyText: Sure. That take makes sense to me, too.
replies.author: jpignata

replies.bodyText:
I do like the expanded examples, though. Could probably split the difference and end up with something like:

This can be a username in the ordinary sense ("superdog22"), or an email address ("superdog22@example.com"), or a phone number ("+12125551212").

For extra credit, each could include a match regex... :-)
replies.author: jamesonwilliams

timeline.bodyText:
Newbie to the project caveats apply:
From the comments and AWSCognitoAuthProvider, it looks like the idea here that a developer would inherit from this class to override it or add additional authentication providers. Given it's holding a single value, are there other mechanisms for extension points that could be easier for a developer to work with, such as using an enum?
